Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Spectrum Situational Awareness-Understanding the Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The key resource shared by all wireless systems is the electromagnetic spectrum, which is challenged by temporal and spatial congestion, interference, and increasing security threats. This project investigates the hypothesis that building a resilient always-on wireless network, capable of meeting ever-increasing performance and security requirements, necessitates not only innovations in radio design but also innovations in the management and exploitation of vast amounts of radio spectrum knowledge. Such knowledge is referred to as spectrum situational awareness - the amount of actionable intelligence and understanding that a wireless network (or individual radio) has about its RF spectrum environment. This research work formally studies the nature of big spectrum data and investigates several critical issues, e.g., how should data from heterogeneous sources be prioritized or weighted, and what are the effects of inaccurate or sparse data measurements.

The scientific goals of this project are to provide foundational principles and insights for developing innovative and scalable spectrum situational awareness architectures, and to enable more efficient and effective uses of the data as well as the improved protocol and system designs. Using formal statistical methods (e.g., regression analysis and response surface methodology) and new big data analytics tools, the research team fully characterizes big spectrum data, its potential impact on spectrum utilization and system performance, and its interaction with the plethora of influential radio, network, and environmental factors. The empirical work is based on experimental scenarios that reflect realistic networking environments, comprising multiple wireless access technologies, interconnected high-speed backhaul networks, and distributed cloud-based technologies. Two testbed instruments are used to design and execute large-scale simulation and emulation experiments: the Distributed Computing and Visual Analytics Sandbox for High Volume Data Streams combined with the Wireless Systems and Performance Engineering Research (WiSPER) laboratory. Additionally, the research team develops a multilayer spectrum situational awareness framework and is deriving performance indices that can be used to quickly quantify and compare the spectrum situational awareness capabilities of network systems. The project engages students from underrepresented groups via ongoing partnerships with Historically Black Colleges and Universities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The EAGER project titled “Spectrum Situational Awareness: Understanding the Data,” and led by Dr. Magdy Bayoumi at the Center for Advanced Computer Studies (CACS), University of Louisiana at Lafayette, addresses the nature of big spectrum data (BSD) and its impact on spectrum situational awareness (SSA). Where SSA is about exploiting high volume spectrum data (SD) for intelligent decision making. The research outcomes are geared toward enhancing the design of network architectures and algorithms for improved spectrum utilization. We develop the framework, modules and models for big spectrum data analytics to aid the derivation of SSA from BSD.

 

To study and understand the nature of big spectrum data, we develop the framework for generating and designing spectrum awareness modules for opportunistic networking. We propose and validate the methodology for defining SA levels and modules (as a framework) and describe the approach for benchmarking network performance and scalability for SA in cognitive radio network. Our approach incorporates the measurements, estimation and prediction of SA parameters and hence considers all the possible network design factors, which not only reveals the true efficacy of SA techniques but also creates a platform for network design optimization. The proposed methodology was presented and published as the “Framework for Generating and Designing Spectrum Awareness Modules for Opportunistic Networking” at the 8th IEEE Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics & Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON 2017) in Colombia University, New York. As an extension of the work, the resulting simulation modules were also used for the work on “Modeling and Performance Simulation of PULSE and MCMAC Protocols in RFID-based IoT Network Using OMNeT++,” which has been submitted for publication in the 2018 IEEE International Conference on RFID. Other extensions of the work include “A PUF-based paradigm for IoT security,” which was presented and published at the 2016 IEEE 3rd World Forum on Internet of Things (WF-IoT) in Reston, Virginia and “Fast Deep Pyramid DPM Object Detection with Region Proposal Networks,” which has be accepted for publication at the IEEE International Symposium on Signal Processing and Information Technology (ISSPIT 2017) at the University of Deusto in Bilbao, Spain.

 

Furthermore, as part of our main research objectives, we proposed a method for determining network performance and scalability index based on spectrum awareness. The proposed method redefines performance and scalability as functions of reliability, computational complexity and latency. We derived SA constants, which can be used to justify and compare SA techniques and algorithms. We then applied the method to improve the accuracy of the conventional cooperative spectrum sensing scheme by iterative normalization of measured, predicted and estimated sensing data. The results were presented and published as “An Energy-Detection-Based Cooperative Spectrum Sensing Scheme for Minimizing the Effects of Noise Power Estimation Error (NPEE) and Received Signal Power Falsification (RSPF)” at the 19th ACM International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM 2016) in Floriana, Malta. In addition, we are currently proofreading two journal drafts titled, “Performance and Scalability Benchmarking of Spectrum Awareness in Cognitive Radio Networks,” and “Big-Spectrum-Data Synthesis for the Detection and Elimination of Uncertainties in Opportunistic Networks” for publication in the IEEE Transaction on Wireless Communication and ACM/IEEE Transaction on Communication respectively.

 

The project is helping to prepare our current master and doctoral students for careers in academia and industry by introducing them to the details of communications network research planning, design and execution. The garnered experience would not only introduce the students to the process of conducting NSF sponsored projects but also make them become familiar with the techniques of generating research ideas, writing proposals and searching for potential sponsors. Our Wireless Systems Performance Engineering Research (WiSPER) laboratory provides the required culture to initiate and develop the interest for a research career not only in academics but also in the industry. One of the graduate students, Alaa Ali, who worked on the project graduated this semester, Fall 2017, with a Ph.D degree in Computer Engineering and has been given the opportunity to further his career, as a graduate engineer, in Boston, Massachusetts. Another graduate student, Ahmed Aly, who worked on the implementation of the proposed methodology in Vehicular Networks (VN) is currently working in Denver, Colorado as an IT specialists. Other students, including Oladiran Olaleye, Haytham Idriss, Kasem Khalil, Tarek Idriss, and Bappaditya Dey, are also learning and working toward obtaining their degrees in computer science/engineering at our University.
